title.narrative: Improve living standards and community environment to the vulnerable families and groups in Homs

description.narrative:
Homs is the third largest city after Damascus and Aleppo in terms of population. Prior to the crisis, around 1.8 million people lived in Homs (2011). Current figures indicate that the total population is only around 1.42 mil., 360,000 of whom are IDPs from different parts of the country. The city of Homs was declared a safe city in May 2018 after Al-Waar area returned to to the GoS control in the Northwest region. Despite the stable security situation, humanitarian needs are increasing with the increasing number of returnees as well as the IDPs who are moving to the governorate from hotspots, especially from Al-Rukban camp. COVID-19 crisis led to massive economic losses in Syria and it has exacerbated pre-existing high level of poverty in Syria generally and in Homs particularly after 9 years of war. In a needs assessment conducted prior to the design of the project, Caritas Homs identified the following priority needs:
1. Survival needs among the most vulnerable 2. Protection needs of civilians
3. Livelihood and essential basic services Therefore, the project will include multipurpose cash to cover basic living needs (food security, shelter and NFIs and Medication), protection activities such as literacy courses, social cohesion activities with youth, psychosocial support to elderly people, income generating activities through trainings, cash grants and toolkit distributions. The project will take place in Homs city and Al-Qusayr in rural Homs.
